ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Respondent

What was the FIRST autism spectrum disorder (ASD) diagnosis you ever received from a professional? Don't know ; 9= Prefer not to answer; 999= Missing data

ElementDescription: What particular abilities or strengths do you have because you are a person on the autism spectrum? Check all that apply or "none of the above" if none apply.
Notes: 1= An ability to think in unusual, creative ways ; 2= An ability to focus intensely on certain topics ; 3= Honesty ; 4= A sense of justice ; 5= A different way of experiencing the world ; 6= Ability in mathematics, science, or computers ; 7= Ability in art or music ; 8= A very good memory for certain topics ; 9= An ability to focus on small details ; 10= An incredible imagination ; 11= Kindness ; 12= Other ; 13= None of the above ; 14= Don't know ; 15= Prefer not to answer; 999= missing data

ElementDescription: Do you have a special interest or topic? (Often individuals with an ASD have an unusually intense area of interest or focus. This is what we mean by special topic.) ; Does the adult have a special interest or topic? (Often individuals with an ASD have an unusually intense area of interest or focus. This is what we mean by special interest or topic.
Notes: 1= Yes ; 0= No ; 2= Prefer not to answer; 999= Missing data

ElementDescription: What type of special interest or topic do you have? Check all that apply if you have more than one.
Notes: 1= Modes of transportation (such as trains, automobiles, aircraft) ; 2= History ; 3= Science (such as astronomy, geology) ; 4= Science fiction or fantasy (in books, films, video games) ; 5= Computers ; 6= Mathematics or numbers ; 7= Animals (such as dogs, fish, horses) ; 8= Movies ; 9= Cartoons or anime ; 10= Maps, calendars, or dates ; 11= Timetables or schedules ; 12= Dinosaurs, monsters, or fictional creatures ; 13= Music ; 14= Art ; 15= Sports ; 16= Sewing or crafts ; 17= Other ; 18= Don't know ; 19= Prefer not to answer; 999= Missing data

ElementDescription: How does your special topic affect your life? Check all that apply or "none of the above" if none apply.
Notes: 1= My job or career involves my special topic. ; 2= My studies in school or college are (or were) related to my special topic. ; 3= I have relationships based on my special topic. I make friends or join groups focused on the same interest. ; 4= I enjoy activities and hobbies relating to my special topic. ; 5= My special topic sometimes gets in the way of success at work, school, or in relationships. ; 6= The special topic has gotten me in trouble. (For example, it may have led to addictive behavior or breaking the law.) ; 7= Other ; 8= None of the above ;9= Don't know ; 10= Prefer not to answer; 999= Missing data

ElementDescription: Is you current work situation regular employment (with no help or support)? ; Is the adults current work situation regular employment (with no help or support)?
Notes: 1= Regular employment (with no help or support) ; 2= Supported employment (you may have a job coach or other special help at work) ; 3= Sheltered workshop ; 4= Enclave employment (you may work in a business with a group of other people with special needs, all under supervision of an agency serving people with disabilities) ; 5= Day program that includes work or vocational activities ; 6= Internship or work study program ; 7= Other ; 8= Prefer not to answer; 999= Missing data

ElementDescription: Is your current work situation supported employment (you may have a job coach or other special help at work)? ; Is the adults current work situation supported employment (they may have a job coach or other special help at work)?
Notes: 1= Unemployed -- want to work but can't find work ; 2= Have tried to work but faced discrimination or other difficulties with employers because of ASD ; 3= Do not wish to work at present (may be in school, a stay-at-home parent, etc.) ; 4= Not able to work because it would interfere with federal or state benefits (such as disability payments) ; 5= Not able to work because the workplace would be too challenging (because of ASD or other health or mental health issues) ; 6= Other ; 7= Prefer not to answer; 999= Missing data

ElementDescription: How much, if any, do you rely on your extended family (such as parents and siblings) for financial support? ; How much does the adult rely on his or her family for financial support?

ElementDescription: Understanding and Accepting Children with ASD (This research will answer questions about how to teach other people, like educators and employers, how children with ASD experience the world, how they feel, why they behave the way they do, and what they need.)
Notes: 1= Extremely high priority ; 2= High priority ; 3= Medium priority ; 4= Low priority ; 5= Not a priority ; 6= Don't know ; 7= Prefer not to answer ; 999= Missing data

ElementDescription: Does the adult use spoken language?
Describe the adult's use of spoken language
Notes: 1 = Language use is completely typical; 2 = There are difficulties mainly with "pragmatic" or social language; 3 = There is difficulty expressing needs using spoken language; 4 = Other

ElementDescription: If other was selected for the adult's use of spoken language, please explain
Does the adult use sign language to help him or her communicate?
Does the adult use high-tech assistive technology (such a voice-output communication device, keyboard, etc.)?
Does the adult use low-tech assistive technology (such as Picture Exchange Communication system, Flip-and-Talk, etc.)?
Does the adult use communication by gesture or behavior?
Does the adult use some other method to help him or her communicate?
If the adult uses some other method to help him or her communicate, please explain
Is the adult able to take a shower or bath without assistance?
Is the adult able to go to the toilet, use the toilet, and return without assistance?
Is the adult able to dress him or herself without assistance (except for tying shoes)?
Is the adult able to tie his or her shoes?
Is the adult able to feed him or herself without assistance?
Is the adult able to shop for him or herself?
Notes: 1 = Can shop for groceries, clothes, and other necessities independently; 2 = Can shop independently for small purchases, but needs assistance with more major purchases; 3 = Needs to be accompanied on all shopping trips; 4 = Is unable to shop

ElementDescription: Is the adult able to prepare food for him or herself?
Notes: 1 = Can plan and prepare meals without assistance; 2 = Can prepare meals without assistance, but needs help with planning; 3 = Needs assistance to prepare meals; 4 = Is unable to participate in meal preparation

ElementDescription: Is the adult able to do housekeeping chores?
Notes: 1 = Can maintain house alone or with very little assistance; 2 = Can't do major cleaning, but can do daily tasks like dish washing and bed making; 3 = Can participate, but needs assistance with all housekeeping tasks; 4 = Is unable to participate in housekeeping tasks

ElementDescription: Is the adult able to do laundry for him or herself?
Notes: 1 = Can do laundry from start to finish without assistance; 2 = Can do laundry with some assistance; 3 = Is unable to do laundry

ElementDescription: Is the adult able to manage his or her own finances?
Notes: 1 = Can independently manage finance-related tasks like going to the bank, writing checks, or paying bills; 2 = Can manage finance-related tasks with assistance; 3 = Is unable to participate in finance-related tasks

ElementDescription: Is the adult able to use the telephone independently?
Notes: 1 = Can both make and take calls without assistance; 2 = Can take calls, but needs assistance to make calls; 3 = Is unable to use the telephone without assistance; 4 = Is unable to use the telephone at all

ElementDescription: Does the adult currently harm him or herself?
Is the adult currently aggressive to others?
Is the adult currently destructive to property (at home or elsewhere)?
Left unsupervised, does the adult ever wander from home such that you worry about his or her safety?
Does the adult show affection to close family members?
Does the adult show interest in social interaction with people outside the family?

A person with ASD may have varied levels of ability across many areas of functioning. Still, it is helpful for researchers to have an overall assessment of functioning level. If you are willing, please indicate your average impression of the adult's overall level of intellectual functioning by choosing from the list below to fill in the blank. The adult functions intellectually at the level of a typical:
Notes: 1 = Infant (younger than 12 months old); 2 = Toddler (1-3 years old); 3 = Pre-school or kindergarten child (4-5 years old); 4 = Early elementary school child (6-8 years old); 5 = Late elementary school child (9-11 years old); 6 = Middle school child (12-14 years old); 7 = High school child (15-18 years old); 8 = Young adult (19-25 years old); 9 = Mature adult (26 years and older)

ElementDescription: If you are willing, please indicate your average impression of the adult's overal level of social functioning by choosing from the list below to fill in the blank. The adult functions socially at the level of a typical:
Notes: 1 = Infant (younger than 12 months old); 2 = Toddler (1-3 years old); 3 = Pre-school or kindergarten child (4-5 years old); 4 = Early elementary school child (6-8 years old); 5 = Late elementary school child (9-11 years old); 6 = Middle school child (12-14 years old); 7 = High school child (15-18 years old); 8 = Young adult (19-25 years old); 9 = Mature adult (26 years and older)
